title: HSS8005 {{< iconify line-md plus >}}
text:
Quantitative analysis 
        
        
            HSS8005 • 2022 • Newcastle University (UK)
        
        
            A second course in applied statistics and probability for the understanding of society and culture.
        
    


Please note that this space is still work in progress. Information and materials will be added and may change before the start of the module in February 2023


Module leader

   Dr. Chris Moreh
   HDB.4.106
   chris.moreh@newcastle.ac.uk
   tutorial booker

title: About
text:
About this site
Nothing important here

title: Data overview
text: We will be using a variety of real-world data from public sources and published research. You can read the data dictionary for each dataset from the side menu. You will be able to access the data from a dedicated  package {hss8005data} (note: work in progress and may be updated during the course).

title: Materials
text: Materials for each week are available from the side menu.

title: Week 1
text:
This week will be a general introduction to the module, probability theory, the history of statistics and the software that we will be using.
The labs will be an introduction to the {tidyverse} dialect of the  statistical programming language via the  API.

Please note that this plan and the content are still work in progress. The info sheets under  are available in a very rudimentary form, just to give some more boring details about how these planned topics map on to statistical methods that will be covered. The topics marked with an * have a very borderline-significant p-value when tested on the null-hypothesis that they have 0 probability of actually being covered in practice. It will depend somewhat on our interests and the pace of our progress through the previous topics.

title: Week 2
text: A broad review of simple linear regression modelling.

title: Week 3
text: Introduction/review of linear regression models with more than one predictor, with a focus on the concept of causation in a regression context and the use of directed acyclic graphs (DAG) as heuristic devices.

title: Week 4
text: An introduction to generalised linear models; logistic and count models.

title: Week 5
text: An introduction to the idea and elementary practice of statistical simulation.

title: Week 6
text: Introduction to time-series, maybe some spatial correlation and multilevel data amd models.

title: Week 7
text: Introduction to factor analysis and Structural Equation Models (SEM).

title: Week 8
text: Introduction to (social) network analysis and a little text analysis.

title: Week 9
text: Introduction to using text as data.

title: Week 10
text: Time for some conclusions and for hoping that we feel we have conquered some of the complications of applying statistical models to understanding human society and culture.
